Comment: Hey all; I'm taking a break from annotating these complex games, so here's a quick, lighter Blitz game to look at. Enjoy!
This is a less-popular response to the English; it's normally used to transpose to something else, like a Slav or Caro-Kann defense.
Everyone is looking at d5.
Everyone is looking at d5.
Everyone is looking at d5.
White builds a strong center while Black prepares to make a pawn thrust to gain space of his own.
White builds a strong center while Black prepares to make a pawn thrust to gain space of his own.
? Well, I didn't see this coming. Black would have been better off continuing with solid play, with perhaps 4...Bb4.
White takes advantage of the weak d6 square.
?! Rather unusual, but this is Blitz after all, so bold-looking sacrifices are the order of the day, sound or not.
?! Rather unusual, but this is Blitz after all, so bold-looking sacrifices are the order of the day, sound or not.

There's really no way for this to accomplish anything.
There's really no way for this to accomplish anything.
Black sets up an outpost on the g3 hole.
Black sets up an outpost on the g3 hole.
This move is intended almost exclusively to provide a space for White's Rook on f1. White is now also in a position to threaten moves like Bh5.
Black is having trouble coordinating his pieces thanks to his early pawn moves.

? Black has the idea of a tactic here to keep White from getting his King to g1, but with only two pieces developed (about to be only one!) he just doesn't have the firepower necessary to get compensation for this Knight, especially since he sacrificed one piece for no compensation already!

Black piles up on the Be3; White defends it. White now has his Rooks connected and a fully developed army, whereas Black has... a Queen and Bishop, and chances for one Rook on the opposite flank several moves down the road.

Black wins back a pawn, but he is so far behind now that in a standard game he should surrender immediately. This is blitz though, so errors are much more likely.
